value.title: IBM's new 2-nm chips have transistors smaller than a strand of DNA
value.excerpt: In a shining example of the inexorable march of technology, IBM has unveiled new semiconductor chips with the smallest transistors ever made. The new 2-nanometer (nm) tech allows the company to cram a staggering 50 billion transistors onto a chip the size of a fingernail.

value.title: States push back against use of facial recognition technology by police
value.excerpt: I think people are just freaked out, and rightfully so, about this technology,” said Freddy Martinez, director of Lucy Parsons Labs, a Chicago nonprofit that specializes in citizens' digital rights.

value.title: Facial Recognition as a Legislative Issue

value.title: POLITICO AI: Decoded: Robot law — Helsinki wants to be Europe’s smartest — China on facial recognition
value.excerpt: How global thinking on AI is shaping the world, from Berlin, Brussels, London and beyond. POLITICO’s AI correspondent cuts through the noise, introduces you to the key decision-makers you’ve never heard of and tells you what those in power don’t want you to know.

value.title: Anyone can use this powerful facial-recognition tool — and that's a problem
value.excerpt: You probably haven't seen PimEyes, a mysterious facial-recognition search engine, but it may have spotted you.

value.title: Missouri woman discovers WWII military device in her backyard
value.excerpt: (CNN)A Missouri woman found more than weeds poking out of the soil in her yard this weekend. Pamela Coffey told CNN that she was just about to take lunch break from doing yard work on Saturday when she spotted a small metal object jutting out from the soil under her feet.

value.title: Computer Vision Remains An Untapped Opportunity In American Industry

value.title: Gnarly Skateboarders Trying Dangerously To Hitch A Ride On Self-Driving Cars
value.excerpt: Skateboarders sometimes try to do bumper hitching, which is dangerous and should not be done, but the question is how will self-driving cars deal with those gnarly riders.

value.title: A scientist created emotion recognition AI for animals
value.excerpt: A researcher at Wageningen University & Research recently published a pre-print article detailing a system by which facial recognition AI could be used to identify and measure the emotional state of farm animals.

value.title: Computer vision inches toward ‘common sense’ with Facebook’s latest research

value.title: From Coral Reefs To Assembly Lines, Computer Vision Gives New View On How To Work Smarter
value.excerpt: Once a thing of science fiction, the vast uses for computer vision technology are now clear. Advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) over the past 10 years have helped scientists develop computer vision technology – an AI application that allows computers to “see” their surroundings and make these visual inputs actionable with 99% accuracy.

value.title: Samsung Bespoke Jet Bot AI Robot Vacuum Cleaner launched in Korea
value.excerpt: Samsung has unveiled the Bespoke Jet Bot AI Robot Vacuum Cleaner designed to significantly improve home cleaning duties. The robot vacuum cleaner features enhanced capabilities for object recognition and adopts artificial intelligence (AI) technology which significantly improves the performance as well.

value.title: False facial recognition sends innocent New Jersey man to jail
value.excerpt: New Jersey police arrested an innocent man on unlawful possession of a weapon, resisting arrest and aggravated assault charges after he was falsely identified by facial recognition technology. value.title: Computer vision in AI: The data needed to succeed

value.title: Increasing use of facial recognition technology in China faces backlash from city governments
value.excerpt: After being highlighted for misuse on China’s annual Consumer Protection Gala in March, several cities in China are tightening the enforcement of regulations on facial recognition.
